Immerse yourself in the world of Claude Monet at the "Monet Inside" exhibition, located on the third floor of Parkview Square.
This captivating experience begins with an introductory room showcasing panels about Monet's life.  The main attraction is a 45-minute multimedia presentation, where stunning visuals and narration bring his art to life, exploring his fascination with light, color, and nature.  A dedicated photo spot allows you to capture memories against a backdrop of his iconic works.

"Monet Inside" offers a unique and immersive experience for art lovers. While the cost is moderately high, it's a worthwhile journey into Monet's genius.  The exhibition is best suited for adults and older children; younger children may find it challenging to remain engaged.

Experience "Monet Inside" in Singapore until April 2025.

After enjoying the Monet digital show, I was excited to experience the Van Gogh edition at the same venue—an elegant and somewhat unexpected space near Bugis MRT, right across from Raffles Hospital.
The theater itself was a pleasant surprise—mid-sized, stylish, and perfect for an immersive art experience.

With Monet, I had the luxury of a nearly empty weekday session, where I could sit right at the front and absorb the stunning visuals in peace.
Van Gogh, however, was a different story—packed and considerably noisier. But knowing what to expect this time, I was able to enjoy it even more.
The concept became clear: an audiovisual journey through an artist’s world, blending breathtaking projections with their life story. The English subtitles were a thoughtful touch, especially for those of us who aren’t native speakers.

The way the visuals covered the entire theater was truly mesmerizing—each painting coming to life in a way that made you feel part of the artwork.
This is what makes these digital exhibitions so special: the ability to step inside the artist’s universe.

Being a VIP ticket holder, I received a lovely fragrance spray as a gift—not once, but twice! (Monet and Van Gogh came with the same VIP present, so now I have four bottles. Not complaining, but a bit of variety would have been nice!)
There was also a tiny sticker pack, but oddly, none featured Van Gogh’s iconic Sunflowers. A curious omission.

Overall, it was a fantastic experience at a reasonable price, and I would gladly return for future editions.
That said, there was one major downside…

During the Van Gogh show, the number of children in attendance was overwhelming.
At times, it felt less like an art exhibition and more like a playground. The “photo-friendly” session, in particular, descended into absolute chaos—kids running wild, screaming, and treating the space like an indoor obstacle course.
While I understand that everyone enjoys art differently, it would have been great if someone, anyone, had stepped in to restore some sense of order.

So, would I recommend it? Absolutely. Would I also recommend bringing noise-canceling headphones and the patience of a saint if attending a weekend or peak-hour session? Definitely.
